title: Groupoid object
text:
In <a href="category%20theory">category theory</a>, a branch of mathematics, a groupoid object in a <a href="category%20%28mathematics%29">category</a> "C" admitting finite <a href="pullback%20%28category%20theory%29">fiber product</a>s is a pair of objects formula_1 together with five <a href="morphism">morphism</a>s formula_2 satisfying the following groupoid axioms
A <a href="group%20object">group object</a> is a special case of a groupoid object.
Examples.
Example: A groupoid object in the category of sets is precisely a <a href="groupoid">groupoid</a> in the usual sense: a category in which every morphism is an isomorphism. Indeed, given such a category "C", take "U" to be the set of all objects in "C", "R" the set of all arrows in "C", the five morphisms given by formula_10, formula_11, formula_12 and formula_13.
Incidentally, one can consider a notion of a semigroupoid (unital semigroup = a category with a single object); but, according to this example, that is nothing but a category; so a groupoid object is really a special case of a "category object", better known as a <a href="stack%20%28mathematics%29">stack</a> (or <a href="prestack">prestack</a>).
A groupoid "S"-scheme is a groupoid object in the category of <a href="scheme%20%28mathematics%29">scheme</a>s over some fixed base scheme "S". If formula_14, then a groupoid scheme (where formula_15 are necessarily the structure map) is the same as a <a href="group%20scheme">group scheme</a>. A groupoid scheme is also called an algebraic groupoid, for example in , to convey the idea it is a generalization of <a href="algebraic%20group">algebraic group</a>s and their actions. When the term "groupoid" can naturally refer to a groupoid object in some particular category in mind, the term groupoid set is used to refer to a groupoid object in the category of sets.
Example: Suppose an <a href="algebraic%20group">algebraic group</a> "G" <a href="Group-scheme%20action">acts</a> from the right on a scheme "U". Then take formula_16, "s" the projection, "t" the given action. This determines a groupoid scheme.
Construction.
Given a groupoid object ("R", "U"), the equalizer of formula_17, if any, is a group object called the inertia group of the groupoid. The coequalizer of the same diagram, if any, is the quotient of the groupoid.
Each groupoid object in a category "C" (if any) may be thought of as a contravariant functor from "C" to the category of groupoids. This way, each groupoid object determines a <a href="prestack">prestack</a> in groupoids. This prestack is not a stack but it can be <a href="stackification">stackified</a> to yield a stack.
The main use of the notion is that it provides an <a href="atlas%20%28stack%29">atlas</a> for a <a href="stack%20%28mathematics%29">stack</a>. More specifically, let formula_18 be the category of <a href="torsor%20under%20a%20groupoid">formula_19-torsors</a>. Then it is a <a href="category%20fibered%20in%20groupoids">category fibered in groupoids</a>; in fact, (in a nice case), a <a href="Deligne%E2%80%93Mumford%20stack">Deligne–Mumford stack</a>. Conversely, any DM stack is of this form.
